title: What is the name of the 2 year diploma course in veterinary nursing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Diploma in Veterinary Pharmacy is a 2-year course for Veterinary Nursing aspirants. It is a diploma level course. This nursing course belongs to the field of veterinary medicine. In addition, candidates who want to enroll in this role will primarily work in the animal health industry. During the course, students will learn about the art of understanding the composition of drugs and medicines. Further, the students can work in a lot of different areas after this course. Some of the options available for you are as follows: Veterinary HospitalsAnimal Behaviour ConsultancyVeterinary Colleges & UniversitiesVeterinary Pharmacist ShopsEligibility The student should have passed 12th or any other equivalent exam.In addition, the applicant should have passed with English, Physics, Chemistry, Biology, and Mathematics from a recognized board.Furthermore, as a Veterinary Nurse your duties will involve the following works: Providing support to animalsAssisting in an operation theatrePreparing patients for surgical proceduresApplying bandages to woundsTo carry out veterinary nurse consultationsTo observe and record the patient’s vital signs, which include temperature, respiration, pain, and pulse.Taking radiographsManaging and supporting teamEducating animal owners on nutrition, and preventative care.Students interested in this course should get training from colleges that offer qualifications accredited by RCVS.

I am going out on a limb because I am confused with the veterinary and nursing combination. I believe the 2 year veterinary program would produce a veterinary tech to assist and work with veterinaries in the pet care area. The 2 year nursing program would produce a nursing degree as a ADN or ASN. ADN is Associate degree in nursing and ASN is a Associate in Science Nursing both of these produce RN’s who are ready to walk in a hospital and begin caring for patients. I started with a EMT, LPN, ASN and then BSN and a year toward my Masters in nursing.
